chunks.en: Is love more important in marriage, or is it family background more important?

Recently, I met someone I like, but their family background is very average (complex family situation). I (OP) am a local and can support myself, and my family conditions are okay (parents have good pensions, own a house, no loans, and have savings); The other party's family conditions are average, and they will hardly be able to provide support after marriage.

OP was very impulsive at the beginning of the relationship, but now that the infatuation stage has passed, I've become more rational and am considering these issues, especially how much it would improve the quality of life if I could have free meals at home, financial support from my parents, and help with childcare.
Also, OP's parents recently underwent surgery, and I deeply realized that taking care of sick elderly parents is really hard.
Love is more important. How many people have you truly been attracted to? But there are many with similar backgrounds in the same neighborhood.

chunks.en: Importance rating, out of 5 points: * Emotional stability, 5 points. Any conflict arises from communication problems, and emotional stability is a guarantee of good communication. * Compatibility, 4 points. A large family gap will have the greatest impact, which is that it will produce different values, which will lead to large differences in the way of looking at things and dealing with things. This is also the main point of conflict. * Parents' satisfaction, 3 points. A marriage that parents don't approve of will inevitably have family conflicts. Two people must be of one mind and make great efforts to improve it. If one person does not actively improve the relationship, this conflict will be amplified. * Agreement on values, 3 points. It is unlikely that the three views are the same. The argument of agreement is more reasonable. It is allowed to have differences, but it is also important to respect each other's ideas. If two people have different perspectives on things, it is difficult to adapt to each other, and one party will inevitably give in, which will easily lead to conflicts over time. * Earning ability, 3 points. Poverty-stricken couples grieve over everything. * Appearance, 2 points. If you donâ€™t like the appearance, you may get bored of looking at it. ps: Love is not included in the scoring, because love is an overall feeling of multiple combinations, and everyone's favorite points are different, so it is difficult to evaluate objectively.
Rather than family background, it's more important to have consistent or similar growing experiences.
@liu731 A distorted market, the bubble is about to burst ğŸ¥°

chunks.en: B men can only find C women, and B women generally look down on B men. This is the market.

Love is more important. As long as it's not extreme poverty alleviation, you can work hard together in the future. If it's just a good match, it's easy to get bored, cheat, divorce, and even a small hardship can disintegrate the marriage.

You should follow your heart on this kind of question and don't ask it online. Have you noticed a problem? The reply volume of online posts about marriage and emotion is the largest, because this is the type of question with the lowest threshold and the greatest difference in opinions and experiences. Anyone can chime in, and it has no reference value.
The OP isn't that in love with her anymore :)
Translation ğŸ˜€: Was infatuated before, but now that I've had enough fun, I find it boring and am starting to consider that the other party's conditions are too poor.
@momo1pm Don't always say other people are too young. Is your value system the only correct one?
@nathadai #19 To be blunt, if these miscellaneous expenses account for a large proportion of your salary, then your two families probably don't have much of a gap...
@r6cb Too young
Mutual love > Compatibility; One-sided love < Compatibility
Generally speaking, people choose those with better conditions for marriage. The fact that you're asking this question means you're actually concerned about social status.

To add: if you're just looking for free meals, childcare, and financial support, then why get married? If you give birth but don't raise them, you don't deserve to be a parent. It's sad that people nowadays don't raise their own kids. It's bad luck for whoever is born into that. The old man downstairs in my building is taking care of two kids and is miserable. My wife said, 'Why give birth if you're not going to raise them?' It's fun when you're doing it, but if you have kids and then have the elderly take care of them, the end result is that you won't have your own old age life when you get old, and your remaining life will be spent raising kids.

Isn't personality and whether your values align the most important thing? Otherwise, even if you are well-matched in terms of background, it will still be difficult to live with someone whose values don't align with yours.
I think love is the prerequisite for entering marriage. Without this prerequisite, married life will lack the original driving force.

I suggest being cautious with women from very average (complex family situations) backgrounds, especially those from reconstituted families with very chaotic family situations. Actually, if possible, it's better to find someone who likes you with a simpler family situation, even if their family background is average. In OP's situation, I really want to suggest giving up, because seeing the phrase 'complex family situation' brings to mind images of a very chaotic family, which could only be handled by someone extremely wealthy. Therefore, in summary, marriage is still about compatibility. It would be most suitable for the OP to find a woman with a simpler family situation, whose family can provide at least some help, and who also really likes the OP.

deepseek: When getting married, love and social status are both very important, but they have different focuses. Love is the emotional foundation of marriage, which determines whether two people can be emotionally attracted to, understand and support each other. Marriage without affection easily lacks intimacy and happiness. Social status involves more realistic factors, such as family background, economic conditions, education level, etc. Similar family background and living habits help reduce marital friction and improve life stability. The ideal situation is to have both, an emotional foundation and a similar living background. If you have to choose, love is more important, because emotion is the core driving force of marriage, and social status can be adapted and adjusted through the efforts of both parties. Ultimately, marriage requires the joint efforts of both parties, and both emotional and realistic conditions need to be carefully considered.
Ordinary folks shouldn't even talk about social status. It's not certain that the situation of the two families won't be reversed in 3-5 years. Compatibility may simply not be attainable at all.
